items.title: A new parameter to capture skipped rows metadata as a column
items.body:
# Overview

Hi,

I'd like to propose a parameter to tabulator called "skipped_rows_capture" or something similar. It takes in a list of dicts, each dict containing a regular expression string with once captured group, and one string that contains a column name. The regular expression is then compared to each skipped row in the data.

For example:
```

skipped_rows_capture = [{ 'regex': '\*\* Latitud (.*)$', 'name': 'latitude' }]
skip_rows = ['**']
```

Would match the comment/skipped line:
```
** Latitud 10 29.99
```

And create a new column
```
latitude,
10 29.99
10 29.99
...
```

---

Please preserve this line to notify @roll (lead of this repository)

items.title: XLSX preserve formatting percentage
items.body:
# Overview
Hi,

There is a bug in the tabulator XLSX parser for the preserve_formatting flag.

Specifically, when cells of type percentage are loaded they are always returned as 0.

The solution is to add
```
# Return percentage formatted cells as is
if excel_number.endswith('%'):
    return value
```
To the beginning of the `convert_excel_number_format_string` function (here https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/blob/master/tabulator/parsers/xlsx.py#L334). This will then return `0.5` for a percentage of `50%`.

Let me know if you're too busy and I should create a fork myself, just figured it was easier for you since you are more frequently pushing to this repo :)

---

Please preserve this line to notify @roll (lead of this repository)

items.title: Problem with xlsx with merged cells and multiline header
items.body:
# Overview

When trying to read the file below, tabulator reads the headers on rows 10-12 incorrectly:
http://mapipcissprd.us-east-1.elasticbeanstalk.com/api/public/population-tracking-tool/data/2017,2020/?page=1&limit=1&condition=A&export=true&country=AF

I used options headers=[10,12], fill_merged_cells=True:
`stream = Stream('http://mapipcissprd.us-east-1.elasticbeanstalk.com/api/public/population-tracking-tool/data/2017,2020/?page=1&limit=1&condition=A&export=true&country=AF', headers=[10,12], fill_merged_cells=True, format='xlsx')
`
I also tried fill_merged_cells=False. 

An example of what's missing can be seen in column K of the spreadsheet. The header should be for that one "Current Phase 1 #" but instead is just "Phase 1 #".

Pandas is able to read it using:
df = pandas.read_excel(url, header=[9, 10, 11])

items.title: Issue with change to chardet
items.body:
# Overview

A script failed with the new Tabulator 1.38.1 and I wondered why. I narrowed it down to the change from cchardet to chardet. For this file: https://api.acleddata.com/acled/read.csv?limit=0&terms=accept&iso=112 cchardet has no issues but chardet gives:

```
  File "/.../tabulator/parsers/csv.py", line 108, in __prepare_dialect
    sample.append(next(stream))
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/encodings/cp1254.py", line 23, in decode
    return codecs.charmap_decode(input,self.errors,decoding_table)[0]
UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x81 in position 35349: character maps to <undefined>
```
I saw an issue https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/issues/265 where someone experienced the opposite: chardet works but not cchardet. Obviously I can set things up to use cchardet, but I'd like to understand a bit better the discrepancies you've found between chardet and cchardet.

---

items.title: Bug in tabulator headers parameter
items.body:
# Overview

We're confused by a behavior of tabulator when parsing multiple rows as header rows.

https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/blob/master/tabulator/stream.py#L607

The line above is an if statement that only adds the value of the row to the header if the value inside that row is not equal to the end of the header that has up to then been generated.

We have an excel sheet with 4 rows to be used as headers.
![Screenshot from 2020-01-06 13-53-12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7134143/71819337-e80d6200-308b-11ea-8080-146cdf40b8d5.png)

The expected header value would be `135 C 182 2` but because 182 ends in 2, the 2 is truncated and the resulting header is `135 C 182`. 

Can we either change this behavior or add a flag to tabulator that will overwrite this behavior?

Thanks!

A basic csv to test this would be:
```
1
1
abc
def
ghi
```

Load as csv, set the header rows to 1 and 2, expected header `1 1` but end up seeing just `1`.

---

Please preserve this line to notify @roll (lead of this repository)

items.title: Add an ability for offline test invocation
items.body:
# Overview

We need a way to run tests offline

# Tasks
- [x] add `@pytest.mark.remote` to all remote tests
- [x] add a note to readme about running all the none remote tests: `pytest -m 'not remote'`

----

__From @jayvdb__

When the test suite is run on an offline worker, there are 20 errors.
This situation is required for distro packaging, as they do builds in isolated VMs to avoid any tainting from online resources.

Some of these are rightly checking online behaviour, in which case the usual trick is use a pytest marker to allow them to be disabled easily, e.g. `pytest -k 'not net'`

However it looks like a lot of these should be loading the data from disk, as the online aspect of the test isnt critical.

items.title: Update dependencies on conda
items.body: It seems like something changed in the dependencies for this package, but it maybe didn't get updated in `conda-forge`? After updating and/or re-creating our environment for PUDL, the software is broken because some of the `tabulator` dependencies are no longer satisfied (e.g. `boto3`). If the missing dependencies are installed manually via `pip` it works, but this will cause our `conda` packaging to fail.

items.title: helpers.detect_encoding detects 'iso-8859-1' instead of UTF-8
items.body:
Hi,

I encounter a problem validating an UTF-8 CSV file where one of the columns has a name containing an accent. But as the CSV file detected encoding is wrong, goodtables reports a `non-matching-header`.

You can [try it online](http://try.goodtables.io/?source=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fetalab%2Fschema-irve%2Fraw%2Fv1.0.2%2Fexemple-valide.csv&schema=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2Fetalab%2Fschema-irve%2Fv1.0.2%2Fschema.json&apiJobId=bd9ddf4c-9ca9-11e9-af5c-0a580a2401c9).

It seems that the problem comes from `helpers.detect_encoding` function (based on python chardet) that detects 'iso-8859-1' instead of 'UTF-8'.

[schema_and_csv_samples.zip](https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/files/3349541/schema_and_csv_samples.zip)

e.g. I have this file:

Totals: | Department | Amount
------- | ---------- | ------
<empty> | Sales    | 1,000,000
<empty> | Marketing | 2,500,000

I want to get a stream that fetches only columns 2 & 3. If I use `post_parse` I can remove the first value but but the stream's `headers` property will still list the 'Totals:' column.

How can it be done?

items.title: `sample` returns inconsistent results
Flawed Logic for Deleting Row Elements Corresponding to Blank Headers
items.body:
https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/blob/545d36a7f9d2244bffaf66be11130e1db0ab446e/tabulator/stream.py#L522

The above code deletes the corresponding elements between rows and blank headers, by storing the index of the blank headers (in an ordered list) and then iteratively deleting elements from the row by the index that corresponds.

The problem is that the elements in the index are iterated in increasing order, which means that if the first element is deleted, the corresponding indices of all the next elements are become wrong, and need to be shifted by -1.

The simple fix is to iterate in reverse, or add a counter`

```python
# Ignore blank headers
if self.__blank_header_indexes:
    i = 0
    for index in self.__blank_header_indexes:
        del row[index - i]
        i += 1
```
OR

```python
# Ignore blank headers
if self.__blank_header_indexes:
    for index in reversed(self.__blank_header_indexes):
        del row[index]
```

items.title: If list of OrderedDict supplied keep order when saving
items.body: If a list of OrderedDict is supplied, then when saving the stream, Tabulator should keep the order of the headers according to the order of the keys in the OrderedDict

items.title: Makefile test fails
items.body:
Hi I cloned the repository and followed the installation instructions.

When running `make test` pylama fails to run because of an invalid escape sequence in the regex pattern of the `detect_html` method in the helpers.py module.

Here's the exact output I am receiving.

```bash
tabulator/helpers.py:102:6: W605 invalid escape sequence '\s' [pep8]
```

The fix should be straight forward with either a raw string or \\ to escape the white space character escape e.g

```python
def detect_html(text):
    """Detect if text is HTML.
    """
    pattern = re.compile('\\s*<(!doctype|html)', re.IGNORECASE)
    return bool(pattern.match(text))
```

I would be happy to submit a PR for this.

items.title: Implement json writer
items.body:
# Overview

For now `tabulator` support only `stream.save(format='csv')` to `csv` format. It's pretty easy to implement `json` writer just porting `writers.csv.CSVWriter` to `writers.json.JSONWriter`.

What we're aiming for:

```python
from tabulator import Stream

with Stream('data.xls', headers=1) as stream:
  stream.save('path.json')
```

And of course it will be a pretty cool and useful feature :+1: 

# Plan

- [ ] port `writers.csv.CSVWriter` to `writers.json.JSONWrter`
- [ ] register new writer in `config.py` (see `WRITERS`)
- [ ] add writing tests to `tests.formats.json`
- [ ] mention writing ability in readme `json` format section

items.title: cchardet old version requirement
items.body: In setup.py, cchardet is confined to be less than 2.0. Is there a reason for this? Why not just use the latest?

items.title: Integers are converted into numbers if source is excel
items.body:
If you try and stream data from following sources: [xslx](https://github.com/frictionlessdata/test-data/blob/master/files/excel/sample-1-sheet.xlsx?raw=true) and [xls](https://github.com/frictionlessdata/test-data/blob/master/files/excel/sample-1-sheet.xls?raw=true). `tabulator.Stream` method transforms integers into the numbers. For instance 

```
# number,string,boolean
# 1,one,true
# 2,two,false

>>>from tabulator import Stream
>>> # xlsx
>>> list(Stream('https://github.com/frictionlessdata/test-data/blob/master/files/excel/sample-1-sheet.xlsx?raw=true').open())
[['number', 'string', 'boolean'], [1.0, 'two', True], [3.0, 'four', False]]
>>> # xls
>>> list(Stream('https://github.com/frictionlessdata/test-data/blob/master/files/excel/sample-1-sheet.xls?raw=true').open())
[['number', 'string', 'boolean'], [1.0, 'two', 1], [3.0, 'four', 0]]
```

Also note `True` and `False` are transformed into `1` and `0` in case of xls

items.title: [discuss] Why we don't support ODS and DataPackages by default?
items.body:
By default, tabulator doesn't support ODS and DataPackages, but supports other arguably less useful formats like `json`, `tsv`, and `ndjson`.

As a library's size doesn't matter much in Python (compared to say JS), I'm inclined in supporting all formats by default, but before would like to know if this caused any issues before.

cc @roll

items.title: Replace
items.body:
As a pipeline user I want to be able to find some strings and replace them automatically when processing data, so I don't need to do it manually.  

As a tabulator-py user I want to find and replace strings in my data, using one simple parameter, so that I don't need to write a post-processor script.

### dataset examples where we need a replace ability
https://github.com/datasets/cash-surplus-deficit/blob/master/scripts/process.py [lines 27,28]  
https://github.com/datasets/co2-ppm/blob/master/scripts/process.sh [line 42]  
https://github.com/datasets/gdp-us/blob/master/scripts/process.py [lines 36-45] 

## Analyse

### replace format
* I will use a dictionary to pass agruments into the `Stream` constructor, so later we could extend 'replace' with more keywords:  
`replace={'old': 'q1', 'new': '-03-31'}`
* For several replacements we could use a list of dictionaries: 
```python
replace=[
    {'old': 'q1', 'new': '-03-31'},
    {'old': 'q2', 'new': '-06-30'}
]
```

* [ ] [+2h] To enable RegExp we could pass `'regex': True`. Here's a real example from the script, that need an automation: `replace('\.|"|,|\'|:|-|\(|\)', '', regex=True)`. 
In such case the parameter will look like that:
```python
replace={
    'old': '\.|"|,|\'|:|-|\(|\)',
    'new': '',
    'regex': True
}
```

* [ ] [+2h] We could specify column to apply replace function to. (e.g we need to replace 'q1' to '-03-31' but there could be 'q1' in other columns, that we are not want to break)
```python
replace={'old': 'q1',
         'new': '-03-31',
         'regex': True,
        'column': N or 'name'}
```


## Tasks

* [x] analyze [30m]
* [x] learn tabulator-py docs, run examples [20m]
* [x] find and analyse the 'Stream' commands parser [20m]
* [x] write tests for a new processor`replace: "old", "new"` [20m]
* [ ] create the function [50m]
* [ ] check all the old and new tests are working [10m]
* [ ] docs: update 'Stream commands' and create a 'replace' section [25m]
* [ ] do post-review fixes [20m]
* [ ] PR to main repo [20m]
* [ ] fix the PR post-review fixes, if any [0..20m]
Overall [4 to 4.5h]

Original: https://github.com/AcckiyGerman/tabulator-py/issues/2

items.title: Skip last rows
items.body:
As a user I want to be able to delete some unnecessary rows at the end of table, so I don't need to do it manually.

## Analyse 

We already have the ability to remove few first rows in tabulator-py, so It would be better to extend this function, e.g.
```
tabulator:
      skip_rows: 2   # skip the 2-nd row
      skip_rows: -2  # skip the 2-nd row, counting from the end
      skip_rows: [1, 2, -1, -2]   # etc
```

items.title: Implement json writer
items.body:
# Overview

For now `tabulator` support only `stream.save(format='csv')` to `csv` format. It's pretty easy to implement `json` writer just porting `writers.csv.CSVWriter` to `writers.json.JSONWrter`.

What we're aiming for:

```python
from tabulator import Stream

with Stream('data.xls', headers=1) as stream:
  stream.save('data.json', property=None, keyed=False, indent=4)
```

Where is `keyed` argument should manage how to save json - as array of arrays OR as array of objects (keyed). A `property` argument is the same as for JSON parser and `indent` argument is self-explanatory.

And of course it will be a pretty cool and useful feature :+1: 

# Plan

- [x] port `writers.csv.CSVWriter` to `writers.json.JSONWrter`
- [x] register new writer in `config.py`
- [x] add writing tests to `tests.formats.json`
- [x] mention writing ability in readme `json` format section

---

See initial discussion - https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/issues/198

items.title: JSON formats
Open archived csv like zip or gz
items.body:
# Overview

It's an arising idea that we could provide an ability to open archived files.

---

_From @mcarans_

Is it possible to read zipped csv (or zipped Excel) with Tabulator? I can see I can pass a format (eg. csv) and some classes have an option "allow_zip", so I tried with the url: https://mdgs.un.org/unsd/mdg/Handlers/ExportHandler.ashx?Type=Csv&Series=710
```
    stream = Stream(url, format='csv', allow_zip=True)
    stream.open()
```

This gave me the error:
`tabulator.exceptions.OptionsError: Not supported options "allow_zip" for scheme "https" and format "csv"`

I can work round it with this somewhat ugly looking code:
```
    openedurl = urllib.request.urlopen(url)
    with ZipFile(BytesIO(openedurl.read())) as my_zip_file:
        source = my_zip_file.open(my_zip_file.namelist()[0])
        data = 'text://%s' % source.read().decode()
        stream = Stream(data, format='csv')
        stream.open()
```

---

_From @avmohan_

Support for gzipped csv files would be nice. 

Equivalent to:
```python
import gzip
import csv
with gzip.open('values.csv.gz') as ifile:
  csv_reader = csv.reader(ifile)
  for row in csv_reader:
    pass
```

items.title: Option to ignore columns with blank headers
items.body:
# Overview

We'd like to have argument to ignore columns with falsy headers.

# Plan

- [ ] provide such an options for `Stream`
- [ ] ignore columns with falsy headers if option is true
- [ ] tests/readme

---

From _@mcarans wrote_

When reading the below file, the stream.headers contains a None field and the rows read in using `stream.read(keyed=True, limit=chunksize)` contain a None key in each dictionary:

http://www.acleddata.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/ACLED-All-Africa-File_20170101-to-20170708.xlsx

Is this correct behaviour and if it is, perhaps there should be an option to ignore headers with None?

Currently I have to do:
```
                for fieldname in stream.headers:
                    if fieldname is not None:
                        schema.append({'id': fieldname, 'type': 'text'})
                    else:
                        nonefieldname = True
...
            rowset = stream.read(keyed=True, limit=chunksize)
            while len(rowset) != 0:
                if nonefieldname:
                    for row in rowset:
                        del row[None]

```

See - https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/issues/180

---

_From @roll_

Current workaround:

```py
from pprint import pprint
from tabulator import Stream

def ignore_columns_with_falsy_headers(extended_rows):
    for number, headers, row in extended_rows:
        cleaned_headers = []
        cleaned_row = []
        for index, header in enumerate(headers):
            if header is not None:
                cleaned_headers.append(header)
                cleaned_row.append(row[index])
        yield (number, cleaned_headers, cleaned_row)

source = 'http://www.acleddata.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/ACLED-All-Africa-File_20170101-to-20170708.xlsx'
with Stream(source, headers=1, post_parse=[ignore_columns_with_falsy_headers]) as stream:
    pprint([header for header in stream.headers if header is not None])
    pprint(stream.read(limit=1, keyed=True)
```

items.title: Headers stream parameter should support multi line header?
items.body:
Example file:
https://data.humdata.org/dataset/985b35e6-4bab-4332-af04-6b146be55eb5/resource/062b661b-77a2-4ce6-9676-6f0732c5714b/download/WFPVAM_MM35_Big-Table.xlsx

In the above file the headers are between rows 8 and 12 eg. for column F, the header consists of text in F9, F10 and F12. 

It would be good to be able to pass in a tuple or something representing the start and end row containing the header eg.
`stream = Stream('../WFPVAM_MM35_Big-Table.xlsx', headers=(8,12), fill_merged_cells=True)`

Thus with `headers=(8,12)`, column F's header should be read as "Seasonally adjusted quarterly change (% change)"

More complicated are the headers in columns L and M where L8 to M10 are merged and consist of one header, but there are subheaders underneath in L11-12 and M11-12.

With `headers=(8,12)`, column L's header should be "Cumulative impact of changes on cost of food basket from previous quarter"
With `headers=(8,12)`, column M's header should be "Cumulative impact of changes on cost of food basket from baseline (%)"

items.title: For Excel input, copy value to all merged cells
items.body:
Excel files can have merged cells. The value needs to be copied to all cells that are merged otherwise what is being read in the stream is not correct. This also affects header parsing since people use merged cells in headers as well.
eg.
Set of merged cells 

| | | | |
| |a| | |
| | | | |
| | | | |

would become:

|a|a|a|a|
|a|a|a|a|
|a|a|a|a|
|a|a|a|a|

Example file:
https://data.humdata.org/dataset/985b35e6-4bab-4332-af04-6b146be55eb5/resource/062b661b-77a2-4ce6-9676-6f0732c5714b/download/WFPVAM_MM35_Big-Table.xlsx

Links that might help:
[merged_cells](http://xlrd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#xlrd.sheet.Sheet.merged_cells)
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41759114/how-to-read-merged-cell-with-xlrd-in-python
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30727017/read-merged-cells-in-excel-with-python

---

# Tasks
 
- [x] fix for `xlsx` format
- [ ] fix for `xls` format

items.title: Support datapackages as data sources
items.body:
[Implementation suggestion]

**Detection** - one of:
- `format` == `datapackage`
- `basename(url)` == `datapackage.json`

**Resolution**:
When `format` is `datapackage`, `url` is resolved according to [data-package-identifier spec](http://specs.frictionlessdata.io/data-package-identifier/#identifier-object-structure)

**Resource selection**:
- An optional `resource` parameter.
  - If numeric: specifies the index of the resource
  - If string: specifies the `name` of the resource (first one that matches)
  - If unspecified: takes the 1st resource

**Resource handling**:
- If *Tabular* data package - iterates on the resource itself, using the schema
- If *Non-Tabular* datapackage - resolves to the file referenced by the resource, and continues regular handling from there.

items.title: Expose list of supported schemes and formats?
items.body:
# Overview

`tabulator` clients prefer to have an access to supported schemes and formats programmatically.

# Ideas

It could be something like:

```
tabulator.SCHEMES -> list
tabulator.FORMATS -> list
```

items.title: Add Google Sheet parser
items.body:
# Description

We would like a Google Sheets parser. This is quite high priority, as we'd like it for direct use in OpenSpending.

Some google sheets are "public on the web", and some need credentials. first implementation can assume public on the web and completely bypass credentials.

items.title: Missing support for not keyed NDJSON sources
items.body:
# Overview

Current NDJSON parser support only keyed source rows. See JSON parser as an example to support both - https://github.com/frictionlessdata/tabulator-py/blob/master/tabulator/parsers/json.py#L59-L71

items.title: importing tabulator takes long time
items.body:
When tabulator gets imported, there is a delay, which is very noticable in the command-line tool, that  uses tabulator. On the laptop it is almost 3 seconds, on the desktop about 1.5 seconds. The cli imports tabulator and jsontablechema through datapackage-py. Commenting out both of them from datapackage-py helps to make cli launch instantly.
It would be nice if anything can be done about it. Like doing most heavy stuff lazily, not at import time.

items.title: Replace chardet by C version (cchardet)
items.body:
# Overview

To improve detection speed we better use - https://github.com/PyYoshi/cChardet

items.title: An approach of handling excel dates
items.body:
# Overview

For now `tabulator` just returns what excel drivers return. Related to #97.

items.title: "Source has been detected as HTML" exception when source is CSV that contains HTML
items.body:
The detect_html method might be too sensitive, and flag valid CSV files as HTML. For instance with the following simple CSV file:

```
col1,col2
val1,"<html>"
```

When I run the the following code:

```
from tabulator import Stream

with Stream('test.csv', headers=1) as stream:
    print(stream.headers)
```

I get the exception:

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "test.py", line 3, in <module>
>     with Stream('test.csv', headers=1) as stream:
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tabulator/stream.py", line 133, in **enter**
>     self.open()
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tabulator/stream.py", line 159, in open
>     self.__detect_html()
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tabulator/stream.py", line 291, in __detect_html
>     raise exceptions.TabulatorException(msg)
> tabulator.exceptions.TabulatorException: Source has been detected as HTML (not supported)

items.title: Simple CLI to read data
items.body:
# Description

All main libraries in the stack provides CLI to simplify access to their features. We could do the same for `tabulator` - simple CLI to read tabulator data from command-line.

items.title: Raise errors on open call instead of constructor call
items.body:
# Overview

Some errors now are raising on `Stream` call instead of `open` call. But failure point should be in one place to catch errors on top layers.
# Tasks
- [x] move `loader/parser` creation to open
- [x] ~~add ability to update options on open call (for jts/dp already created streams)~~ (let's do it when there will be concrete request for it)

items.title: Add force parse option to ignore parsing erorrs
items.body:
# Overview

It should be investigated - it looks like if inside an interator has been raised an exception the iterator client can't continue an iteration. So even `try: next(iterator), except` will not help. So may be option to ignore parse errors is needed. The same could be for cast errors on jts.Table.

If force parse is true returned row one error will be none / error instance.

Additional investigation - `Parser.extended_rows` -> `Parser.next` etc?

items.title: Add force strings option to stringify output
items.body: Add a switch in the `Stream` constructor to force all fields as strings. Currently it seems that this feature would only be relevant for Excel sources. See discussion [here](https://github.com/os-data/eu-structural-funds/issues/112).

items.title: Rebase on linear-tsv-v1
items.body: https://github.com/solidsnack/tsv/issues/7#issuecomment-246887336

items.title: Merge loader/parser_options to option keywords in stream constructor?
items.body:
# Overview

`tabulator` constructor options is a standard protocol to open a stream for libraries on top it (`jts.Table`, `goodtables` etc). So we need here user-friendly solution.
# Example

Before:

``` python
stream = Stream('path.csv', parser_options={'delimeter': ','})
```

After:

``` python
stream = Stream('path.csv', delimeter=',')
```
# Tasks
- [x] add to `loaders.Api.supported_options` attribute
- [x] add to `parsers.Api.supported_options` attribute
- [x] add to `writers.Api.supported_options` attribute
- [x] merge `Stream` constructor `loader/parser_options -> **options`
- [x] route passed to `Stream` options based on supported options
- [x] rename `**writer_options` to `**options` in `Stream.save`

items.title: Better error hierarchy
items.body:
# Overview

Client libraries like `goodtables` should know type of error (http, io etc) - see https://github.com/frictionlessdata/data-quality-spec

Proposed error hierarchy:

```
- TabulatorException
  - SourceError
  - SchemeError
  - FormatError
  - EncodingError
  - OptionsError
  - IOError
  - HTTPError
  - ResetError
```
# Tasks
- [x] implement new exceptions and rebase on it
